I would like to answer with a little -- in a little more detail the question which Mr. Justice Marshall asked me about whether or not returns are required.

I knew that annual returns were required, but I wasn’t concerned -- I didn’t, my recollection wasn’t too clear on just what was required in those returns as to the continuing of material relating to continued tax exemption.

I am now advised that you are required to state whether or not you have made any change in your activities, but other than that, the return is one of financial information and of course, it would not catch a situation or trigger a situation where perhaps the Commissioner has changed his view as to situations such that might have here.
I’d like to reply very briefly to counsel suggestion that the size of the employment taxes has some factor.
I don’t think it has anything to do with it at all.

He can sue for $10 and in that proceeding argued that he is an exempt -- he represents an organization exempt under 501 (c) (3) and I think had he done so, this question would have been decided by and now and has been decided on its merits.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But is it true that he wants something more than get a refund of that unemployment tax?

turn.speaker: scott_p_crampton
turn.label: Mr. Scott P. Crampton
turn.text: Well, he wants a determination that he is an exempt organization and I think he would have gotten it in the proceeding.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Which has many -- much broader tax implication than just the refund of the employment taxes?

turn.speaker: scott_p_crampton
turn.label: Mr. Scott P. Crampton
turn.text: No, because I think to get the refund of employment taxes the court would there to determine --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Oh, I understand that.

turn.speaker: scott_p_crampton
turn.label: Mr. Scott P. Crampton
turn.text: -- that the an organization is exempt under 501 (c) (3).
Now to the extent that he may say -- be saying, “I want to do something for other organizations,” our position is that’s not the case here.
We’re talking about “Americans United.”

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Would IRS be required to follow that as to their contributors?

turn.speaker: scott_p_crampton
turn.label: Mr. Scott P. Crampton
turn.text: Well, as to future --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I thought IRS could go along with what the court said about it, whichever way it chose?

turn.speaker: scott_p_crampton
turn.label: Mr. Scott P. Crampton
turn.text: I think they would and I think that’s their policy and we certainly would -- assuming the organization continued to operate the same way in later years that it was in the time of the test case, I think that would be a complete answer and they put their name back.
They do require them to file an application.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That case was -- do you mean that IRS is required to follow that as to contributors?
The IRS says you don’t have to pay these taxes.
Can IRS also say, but we will still deny tax exemption to the contributors?

turn.speaker: scott_p_crampton
turn.label: Mr. Scott P. Crampton
turn.text: Well, the way the procedure that they have is the IRS after case like that ask you to submit an application referring to the case as the reason for that you’re now qualified as tax-exempt organization.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, let me put it --

turn.speaker: scott_p_crampton
turn.label: Mr. Scott P. Crampton
turn.text: And they would then put your name back on the list.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: There’s no requirement though?
That would be up to IRS, wouldn’t it?

turn.speaker: scott_p_crampton
turn.label: Mr. Scott P. Crampton
turn.text: Well, I think that’s right, Your Honor, but I think you could assume a good faith with the Government in a situation like that.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Unemployment taxes, if they were exempt would they be able to pay those voluntarily and cover their employees?
If they were exempt in Section 3, organization?

turn.speaker: scott_p_crampton
turn.label: Mr. Scott P. Crampton
turn.text: I am not sure of that question, Your Honor.
I know they can under Social Security taxes, whether they can under employment taxes, I don’t know.
I would like to comment just briefly on the Allen case.
In that situation, the University of Georgia was a collector of taxes.
It was not a taxpayer and so it had not means of independent judicial review and I think that completely distinguishes that case.

And if all that the respondent wants is a determination of the word “substantial” should be read out of Section 501 (c) (3), we think they could have had that holding if their right made in a refund suit and that’s the place to do it.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Maybe I -- you answered this and I haven’t followed you.
A refund suit on the FUTA taxes would not answer the 501 (c) (3) issue, would it?

turn.speaker: scott_p_crampton
turn.label: Mr. Scott P. Crampton
turn.text: It’s our view that it would because that suit would be based on the theory that we are an exempt organization under Section 501 (c) (3) and therefore we don’t have to pay the FUTA taxes and if the Court agreed with them, you’d have a determination that it was an exempt organization.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Until this revocation Americans United did not pay FUTA taxes?

turn.speaker: scott_p_crampton
turn.label: Mr. Scott P. Crampton
turn.text: That’s right.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And that’s what triggered the payment of FUTA taxes?

turn.speaker: scott_p_crampton
turn.label: Mr. Scott P. Crampton
turn.text: That’s right.
Yes.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you Mr. Crampton.
Thank you gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
